results.title: An Asylum-Seeker’s Wrenching Decision: Stay on the Run or Save His Child’s Life?
results.abstract: As a humanitarian crisis grows on Poland’s border, where the government has taken a hard line on migrants, one father had to decide whether to save an ailing baby girl and risk being expelled.
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

results.title: Earthquake Kills at Least 20 in Pakistan
results.abstract: The 5.7 magnitude quake struck Thursday morning while most people were asleep, and officials feared the toll may rise.

results.title: Dubai’s Ruler Hacked Phones of His Ex-Wife and Her Lawyers, U.K. Court Says
results.abstract: The sheikh, embroiled in a court case with his former wife, a Jordanian princess, used Israeli software to hack the phones. One of the lawyers targeted is a member of Britain’s House of Lords.
results.byline: By Megan Specia and Ben Hubbard

results.title: Boris Johnson Pledges Transformed Economy for U.K.
results.abstract: The prime minister sketched a vision of Britain on the cusp of change, but barely mentioned the spate of fuel and food shortages that have afflicted the country in recent weeks.
results.byline: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle

multimedia.caption: Prime Minister Boris Johnson, speaking at his Conservative Party’s annual conference, said Britain would break from an economic model of “low wages, low growth, low skills.”

results.title: A Sea of White Faces in Australia’s ‘Party of Multiculturalism’
results.abstract: A young daughter of Vietnamese refugees was set to run for Parliament. Then she was passed over for a white insider, and a debate over cultural diversity flared into the open.

multimedia.caption: Tu Le in Cabramatta, a suburb of Sydney, on Thursday. She had been set to become the opposition Labor Party’s candidate for Parliament in one of Sydney’s most diverse districts.

results.title: Vatican Issues Acquittals in Sexual Abuse Case Involving Former Altar Boys
results.abstract: One defendant, now a priest, had been accused of sexual abuse when he and his accuser were teenage students at a seminary within the Vatican walls. Another priest was accused of covering it up.

multimedia.caption: St. Peter’s Basilica in Vatican City in 2020. Both defendants had denied any wrongdoing and said that their accuser had been motivated by a personal vendetta.
St. Peter’s Basilica in Vatican City in 2020. Both defendants had denied any wrongdoing and said that their accuser had been motivated by a personal vendetta.

results.title: Behind the Global Appeal of ‘Squid Game,’ a Country’s Economic Unease
results.abstract: The dystopian Netflix hit taps South Korea’s worries about costly housing and scarce jobs, concerns familiar to its U.S. and international viewers.

results.title: Germany Sets Aside an Additional $767 Million for Holocaust Survivors, Officials Say
results.abstract: Many of those now eligible for reparations are Russian Jews who survived the Nazi siege of Leningrad. They will receive annual pensions of about $5,200, or 4,500 euros.
des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
org_facet: Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany

results.title: English Schools Drop Mask Mandates, but Questions Rise Along With Cases
results.abstract: England is taking more risks than many U.S. schools as a way of returning to normal. Many parents approve, but with more than 180,000 students absent in recent weeks, others question the trade off.
results.byline: By Mark Landler and Megan Specia

results.title: After Pastor Evicts Nearly 200 Migrants, His Brother Welcomes Them All
results.abstract: An evangelical minister in a Mexico border town had let dozens of migrant families live in his church. When he ousted most of them, his brother across the way invited the outcasts into his home.

results.title: A New Vaccine Strategy for Children: Just One Dose, for Now
results.abstract: Myocarditis, a rare side effect, occurs mostly after the second dose. So in some countries, officials are trying out single doses for children.

multimedia.caption: A teenager being vaccinated in Minneapolis in May. Concerns that a tiny number of young people, mostly boys, may experience myocarditis have led some countries to recommend a single dose of the vaccine.

results.abstract: Malaria kills about 500,000 people each year, about half of them children in Africa. The new vaccine isn’t perfect, but it will help turn the tide, experts said.

results.title: Outlook for Iran’s Longest-Held Americans Echoes Broader Relationship: Dismal

results.title: Covid shots saved the lives of 39,000 older or disabled Americans through May of this year, the U.S. reports.
results.abstract: An analysis published by the Department of Health and Human Services said that Covid shots had also prevented about 265,000 cases and 107,000 hospitalizations.

results.title: Boris Johnson Urges Businesses to Help Resolve Britain’s Shortages
results.abstract: The prime minister said current supply-chain disruptions were an inevitable step to a more robust economy.

results.title: A maker of rapid Covid tests recalls nearly 200,000 kits over concerns of false positives.
results.abstract: The company, Ellume of Australia, traced the problem to variations in the quality of a single, unnamed material.

results.title: Blinken, in Paris, Tries to Restore Trust After Submarine Snub
results.abstract: The American secretary of state met privately with the French foreign minister for more than an hour. But French anger remained palpable, even as both sides tried to move on.
results.byline: By Lara Jakes and Steven Erlanger
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
org_facet: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development

multimedia.caption: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, right, met on Tuesday with the French foreign minister in Paris.

results.title: Johnson & Johnson seeks F.D.A. authorization for its booster shot.
results.abstract: The company said that a second shot of its vaccine about two months after the first significantly boosts protection to 94 percent against moderate to severe disease.
results.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
